--- title: Gluteus Medius subtitle: The Main Hip Abductor --- ![Hip and Thigh Muscles @OpenStaxAnatomyPhysiology2022](/The Archive/Images/OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology 2e/fig11.29 Hip and Thigh Muscles.jpeg){#fig-openstax-fig11.29} ![Muscles of the gluteal and posterior femoral region @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Myology/image434 Muscles of the gluteal and posterior femoral regions.gif){#fig-gray1918-image434} ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Gmed muscle @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 - Neuman @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 ::: ::: {#tbl-glute-ed-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Gluteus medius Ilium Greater trochanter (lateral surface) Superior gluteal n.
L4 - S1		 Entire mm.: Abduction, Frontal stabilization
Anterior fibers: Flexion, IR
Posterior fibers: Extension, ER (when <60° HF), IR (when >60° HF)
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Ilium (gluteal surface below the iliac crest between the anterior and posterior gluteal line) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} Greater trochanter of the femur (lateral surface) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} The gluteus maximus muscle is innervated by nerve roots [L4]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l4 >}}), [L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}}), and [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}}), via the [Superior gluteal nerve]({{< var ref-superior-gluteal-nerve.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - **Entire muscle**: abducts the hip, stabilizes the pelvis in the coronal plane @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - **Anterior fibers**: flexion and internal rotation @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - **Posterior fibers**: extension and external rotation @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - At ≥60° hip flexion, the *posterior fibers* of the gluteus minimus switch and produce an *internal rotation* torque @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The Glute med is the "main hip abductor" due to its efficiency and strength. The Glute med is efficient since it is almost perpendicular to its lever arm @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The glute med and glute min are both oriented mostly in the frontal plane, but the glute med is a greater abductor since it can produce ~16kg of force, which is more than 3x that of the gluteus minimus @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The glute med's insertional angle on the greater trochanter varies with degree of hip abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. At neutral, the angle is *not* perpendicular, thus the force generate by the glute med results in a hip abduction moment *and* joint compression which increases articular contact @jonesProjectFoundations2025. As the hip moves into abduction, the insertional angle becomes more perpendicular, resulting in a greater hip abduction moment and decreased hip joint approximation force @jonesProjectFoundations2025. This trend continues until the hip reaches 35° abduction, which is exactly perpendicular @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Overview # Palpation {#palpation}
  1. Position the patient in sidelying [@bielTrailGuideBody2019]
  2. Much of the glute medius and minimus overlap, but you can isolate the gluteus medius by palpating the most superior part of the iliac crest [@bielTrailGuideBody2019].
  3. The glute med's proximal origin extends from the PSIS almost to the ASIS [@bielTrailGuideBody2019].
  4. The fibers of the glute med and min are fanned across the iliac crest then converge distally at the greater trochanter of the femur[@bielTrailGuideBody2019].
  5. To palpate the [gluteus minimus]({{< var ref-gluteus-minimus.palpation >}}), dive deep to the the gluteus medius
  6. Having the patient actively abduct the top leg will help confirm that you are palpating the correct muscle [@bielTrailGuideBody2019].
# Tests & Measures - External Derotation Test (gluteus medius tendinopathy) # Exercise A wedge forcing the foot into hyper-dorsiflexion will cause the client to prevent excessive anterior knee translation and force more hip hinge, which will activate the glutes. - Single leg bridge (with 90° knee flexion and pushing through the hindfoot) - Wall triple extension - Bridge (toes up) - S/L Hip abduction to high knee
